item.title: Whats popular on the web for #technology?
item.dc:creator: jeffield
item.content:encoded:
What is popular on the web for 'hashtag technology'?

AKA: Learn some stuff for the StackOverflow's history.

Today, I got sent an email about this guy 'Felix Arvid Ulf Kjellberg' or 'PewDiePie'. Turns out his youtube channel has over 25 million subscribers. I asked my teenager's if they knew who he was and they did, of coarse they did.. our house is wired for the internet. Actually, after seeing who he was and sampling a bit of his content I realized that I had seen him on my computer in the past as I got drawn into my office as my son was in an all out belly laugh. Yea, and so what..? why do I care about that? I agree, I am way past my internet-gaming days. Why..? well here is 7 million reasons why.

This got me to thinking about allot of things but one of the threads that kept running through my mind was.

What is popular on youtube, and why?

I did a bit of research of what is really gathering hits on youtube. I was quickly disinterested in most of the top content. I did find this guy 'Peter Oakley: The internet grandad' or 'geriatric1927' to be quite refreshing.

In the end, ended up where I always do, hunting down technology and I stumbled upon this 10 Technology YouTube Channels You Can't Miss

Of these I really like these two: Google Talks and Life Hacker

Grabbing a quick bite to eat I fired up our PS3, which I stream content from. I fired up youtube and searched for the Google Talks on the PS3 google app. This app always has interesting 'very different search results': I ended up stumbling across this 'old-ish' talk by Joel Spolsky.  'Learning from StackOverflow.com (2009)'

Among other things, I learned that Jeff Attwood's blog and 'Joel Spolsky' had super popular technology blogs. Around 1 million page views a month. ( at the time )  These numbers were used to 'fill-the-pipe' with users when the StackOverflow site launched in-beta. Which was fairly important because the nature of the site required people to provide answers out of the gate. Aside: I did not know about Joel's page so looking forward to reading some of those entries in-spite of Wasabi (2006). So in the end, I wrote this entry so I could create these links.

  • Google Talks
  • Life Hacker
  • coding horror
  • joelonsoftware
  • discourse ( Jeff's new idea )
  • Fog Creek ( Joel's Development company )
  • 04-16-2008 What StackOverflow will be... Posdcast
  • transcribed podcast
  • April 2008: StackOverflow Name our Website

item.title: Im Back
item.dc:creator: jeffield
item.content:encoded:
I have now spent years without an internet presence. I have struggled with coming back many times, facebook made publishing so easy and care-free. But now...

Im baa....ack

I have built many websites and the fun had worn off and it turned into work. Finally I decided that it's sort-of silly to claim to be a web developer with nothing to show for it in the cloud. Not having a presence on the web was bothering me. The time has come to start bringing my notes and reference back into the web-sphere so hopefully others could benefit.

[caption id="attachment_25" align="alignnone" width="527"] The last time I had a web presence was before these guys were born[/caption]

I spend a lot of time researching web-technologies at my day-job.  The purpose of this site is to capture some of the more interesting things I have learned along the way. Things that I have a tendency to forget.

Getting back into the net

Being a web developer I spent many hours making this way more difficult than it needed to be. Finally after reading Kenneth Reitz Why I left Medium, I decided that I would follow suit. There is no point in getting caught up in writing code [an easy trap for me] while trying to communicate my thoughts.  So you are viewing the result of my 'cough-cough' php based wordpress site.

item.title: The web request is a scary place
item.dc:creator: jeffield
item.content:encoded:
While dealing with a server cpu spiking issues.  I stumbled onto a great conference talk given at PyCon 2013. The title of the talk was 'Messaging at Scale at Instagram'.  Yea let that sink in a bit.

...Instagram...

Right, they serve up millions page-hits a day. So probably should listen and learn from there experiences. This talk was given by Rick Branson.  I wrote this entry so I would not loose the link to this presentation which is jam-packed with information. This quote from the talk really resonated with me:

“The web request is a scary place, you want to get in and out as quick as you can”  - Rick Branson

This resonated with me because yea, it is scary... and at the time the web-request was killing me. For the life of me, I could not get outta there fast enough. This become my mantra as I struggled with my project with the scaling issue. I went after all of the typical software engineering low-hanging-fruit. Profiling specific areas of standalone code, outside of the web request. Time-it, make it faster, and time it again. I also used NewRelic to do the same, while in a production environment.  This is a highly recommended tool. After all of my efforts I was only able to eek out a bit more performance.

The basic architecture that I had that was not working. So after falling in love with the quote 'the web request is a scary place you need to get in and out of there as quick as you can' I wrestled with the question.

how quick is that?

How long can I stay in the web request? Without causing scaling out problems? Rick actually addresses it in his talk, he states you want to get out of that web request in 100 ms to 500 ms

So ok, great... but how do I do that?

Turns out I had three problems:
  • apache/mod_wsgi configuration issues
  • pore preforming code
  • architecture issue

Before listening to Rick's talk I was completely dialed-into the pore preforming code part of the problem. Which I could still be working on and still having my cpu spiking issues under relatively low load situations.

I cover my apache/mod_wsgi configurations issues to another entry 'Stop miss-configuring Apache and mod_wsgi'. Which includes lots of great links to subject matter on the topic. Including a link to another solid-gold PyCon 2013 talk by Graham Dumpleton.

Now for the Juggernaut problem: Architecture Issue

Basically what I learned from Rick's talk was that I needed to build a Asynchronous Tasking/Queuing system. This system would give me the ability to have ‘long running tasks'/ 'transcoding' capabilities. I could now pull my time consuming logic outta the web request and execute it in a task. Thus giving me the ample performance increase I was after.

Enter Celery Choose a AMQP broker Enter RabbitMQ Need to talk to this broker with python Enter Pika Pick Caching solution Enter Memcached
“There is no such thing as running tasks exactly-once.” - Rick Branson
Just to point out that Instagram did not invent these ideas or concepts. Lets lean on the pre-web history a bit.
“... it is impossible for one process to tell whether another has died ( stopped entirely ) or is just running very slowly.” Impossibility of distributed consensus with one faulty process Fisher, N. Lynch 1985
What the architecture looks like now.

The 'Broker', 'Queues' are part of the RabbitMQ setup. The 'Workers' are from celery and the new Cache is an instance of Memcached.

For reference my server spike issues are gone now and I sleep better at night. As an added benefit I can now scale horizontally quite nicely.

References:

  • Scaling Python Django application with apache and mod_wsgi
  • Common Setups for your web application
  • TODO: add Graham Duplington's doc.
  • Django performance patterns
  • doesdjango scale
  • AMQP ‘Advanced Messaging and Queuing Protocol’

item.title: Changing the host name in a WordPress app
item.dc:creator: jeffield
item.content:encoded:
This entry is going to cover how to change your hostname entries in a WordPress app. A small bit of this entry will be pagodabox specific, but I will point that out along the way.

Overview

When you use WordPress its dbms schema will embed your hostname into the dbms in several locations. This for the most part is not troublesome until you decide to move your app to another machine, or change your hostname. The later usually occurs when you decide that your blog is ready for prime time, and its time to buy that fancy doamin name. This will guide you through the steps of making the change to those entries.
  1. Log into your dbms
  2. change the home and site_url options in the wp_options table
  3. change the guid values in the wp_posts table
  4. update the post_content in the wp_posts table

 1: Log into your DBMS

Here I am are going to be a bit pagodabox specific. Follow this guide on how to create an ssh tunnel into your dbms. You will be using the pagoda terminal client and you will be creating a ssh tunnel to your dbms.     Once you have your ssh tunnel created, you should have a port [3307] forwarded to your local machine. Now you simply need to log into your mysql database like it was a local database on your machine.  

2:3:4: Change dbms contents

Alright you are now ready to do the dbms content modifications. You are now done, enjoy the fact that your uri's stay the same while clicking through your site.

Reference:

  • Creating a Secure ( pagodabox) Database Tunnel
  • 13 Useful WordPress SQL Queries
  • Installing the pagoda terminal client
  • Wordpress Database Description
